Situation1: Help each other in times of need or emotional distress.
Expectation2: Ensure client satisfaction and address any concerns or complaints professionally
Situation2: A first-time visitor looks disappointed with the colour tone in the mirror.
Story: I was sweeping up hair clippings when my phone buzzed with a message from my sister: “Can you call? I really need you.” She never asked for help unless it was serious. My heart clenched, but just then, my next client—a first-time visitor—settled into my chair. She wanted a bold new colour, and I’d done my best, but as she stared into the mirror, her lips pressed into a thin line. “It’s… not quite what I expected,” she said quietly, her disappointment clear. I could feel the weight of her expectation—she needed me to listen, to fix it, to make her feel beautiful and heard. At the same time, my sister’s message echoed in my mind, her need for support pulling at me. I stood there, scissors in hand, torn between the urge to step away and call my sister, and the responsibility to stay and help my client. My chest tightened as I wrestled with the impossible choice, both roles demanding all of me at once.
